evidence.pdf_reference: by Usubharatana et al., the enhancement of photocatalytic activity for the reduction of CO 2 is primarily based on a high efficiency of the semiconductor photocatalyst. 32Here the hierarchically mesostructured TiO 2 GC composite was used as a photocatalyst to convert CO 2 and H 2 O into CH 4 and CO under simulated solar irradiation.The photocatalytic performances of the meso-TiO 2 , TiO 2 SiO 2 composite and commercial Degussa P25 titania were also carried out under the same experimental conditions for

experimental conditions for comparison.Additionally, in order to investigate whether other possible carbon sources in the TiO 2 GC composite produced CO or CH 4 during the photocatalytic process, a control experiment using Ar instead of CO 2 was carried out under the same experimental conditions.The results from the GC analysis show that no CO or CH 4 appear in the absence of CO 2 after an irradiation time of 320 min, suggesting that the origin of carbon in CO and CH 4 is ascribed to the photoreduction of

to the photoreduction of CO 2 with H 2 O on the TiO 2 GC composite.Fig. 5 shows the time profiles for the yields of products under irradiation with simulated solar.It can be observed that the yields of CH 4 and CO increased with the irradiation time for all samples.The meso-TiO 2 exhibited a higher photocatalytic activity compared to commercial P25, which may be ascribed to its high specific surface area and mesostructure.Meanwhile the activity of the TiO 2 SiO 2 composite was very close to that of the

were carried out on a RBO upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) using monochromated Al K X-rays (h 1486.6eV) as the radiation source at 250 W. All binding energies were calibrated using the contaminant carbon (C 1S 284.6 eV) as a reference. The photocatalytic reaction was carried out in a stainless steel reactor with a volume of 1500 mL (as shown in Fig. S2,ESI ).The catalyst powder (0.10 g) was dispersed on the stainless steel omentum, which was fixed in the center of the reactor.The bottom of the

of graphitic carbon.This is helpful for the separation of the photogenerated electronhole pairs in TiO 2 , which results in an improved photocatalytic activity under solar irradiation (as shown in Fig. 6).Finally, XPS analysis confirmed that a high surface concentration of hydroxyl groups existed on the surface of the TiO 2 GC composite, which led to an easier electron flow on the external surface of the TiO 2 GC composite and thus suppressed the recombination rate of the photogenerated electron-hole

result.query:
Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
Light_source: XXX
Lamp: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: the reactor.The bottom of the glass wool support was moisturized with 5.0 g of deionized water to maintain a saturated water vapor in the reactor.A Xe arc lamp (300 W) with a sun-like radiation spectrum was put at the top of the quartz window at a distance of 8 cm, which irradiated all of the catalyst powder.In order to control the reaction temperature, the Xe lamp was placed in a cold trap and the whole reactor system was surrounded by air circulation.Prior to illumination, the reactor was first purged

the reactor was first purged with the CO 2 H 2 O mixture at 100 mL min -1 for 2 h and then reduced to 20 mL min -1 for another 1 h to establish an adsorption-desorption balance.After that, the reactor was tightly closed and the Xe lamp was then switched on to start the experiment.The reaction temperature and pressure were maintained at 30 C and 110 KPa, respectively.The gas phase products were taken at various times during the irradiation and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC).

were carried out on a RBO upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) using monochromated Al K X-rays (h 1486.6eV) as the radiation source at 250 W. All binding energies were calibrated using the contaminant carbon (C 1S 284.6 eV) as a reference. The photocatalytic reaction was carried out in a stainless steel reactor with a volume of 1500 mL (as shown in Fig. S2,ESI ).The catalyst powder (0.10 g) was dispersed on the stainless steel omentum, which was fixed in the center of the reactor.The bottom of the
photogenerated electron-hole pairs.

were carried out on a RBO upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) using monochromated Al K X-rays (h 1486.6eV) as the radiation source at 250 W. All binding energies were calibrated using the contaminant carbon (C 1S 284.6 eV) as a reference. The photocatalytic reaction was carried out in a stainless steel reactor with a volume of 1500 mL (as shown in Fig. S2,ESI ).The catalyst powder (0.10 g) was dispersed on the stainless steel omentum, which was fixed in the center of the reactor.The bottom of the

experimental conditions for comparison.Additionally, in order to investigate whether other possible carbon sources in the TiO 2 GC composite produced CO or CH 4 during the photocatalytic process, a control experiment using Ar instead of CO 2 was carried out under the same experimental conditions.The results from the GC analysis show that no CO or CH 4 appear in the absence of CO 2 after an irradiation time of 320 min, suggesting that the origin of carbon in CO and CH 4 is ascribed to the photoreduction of

stirring for 120 min, the mixture was transferred to a clean flat Petri dish (diameter: 10 cm) and then left at room temperature for a day to allow the solvent to evaporate leaving a rigid gel.This gel was calcined at 900 C under Ar flow for 4 hours with a heating ramp of 1 C min -1 to decompose and carbonize the precursors.Finally, the silica matrix was removed using a 2 M NaOH aqueous solution and this etching process was repeated three times.The resulting composite photocatalyst is denoted as TiO 2

evidence.pdf_reference: the reactor.The bottom of the glass wool support was moisturized with 5.0 g of deionized water to maintain a saturated water vapor in the reactor.A Xe arc lamp (300 W) with a sun-like radiation spectrum was put at the top of the quartz window at a distance of 8 cm, which irradiated all of the catalyst powder.In order to control the reaction temperature, the Xe lamp was placed in a cold trap and the whole reactor system was surrounded by air circulation.Prior to illumination, the reactor was first purged

the reactor was first purged with the CO 2 H 2 O mixture at 100 mL min -1 for 2 h and then reduced to 20 mL min -1 for another 1 h to establish an adsorption-desorption balance.After that, the reactor was tightly closed and the Xe lamp was then switched on to start the experiment.The reaction temperature and pressure were maintained at 30 C and 110 KPa, respectively.The gas phase products were taken at various times during the irradiation and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC).

experimental conditions for comparison.Additionally, in order to investigate whether other possible carbon sources in the TiO 2 GC composite produced CO or CH 4 during the photocatalytic process, a control experiment using Ar instead of CO 2 was carried out under the same experimental conditions.The results from the GC analysis show that no CO or CH 4 appear in the absence of CO 2 after an irradiation time of 320 min, suggesting that the origin of carbon in CO and CH 4 is ascribed to the photoreduction of

were carried out on a RBO upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) using monochromated Al K X-rays (h 1486.6eV) as the radiation source at 250 W. All binding energies were calibrated using the contaminant carbon (C 1S 284.6 eV) as a reference. The photocatalytic reaction was carried out in a stainless steel reactor with a volume of 1500 mL (as shown in Fig. S2,ESI ).The catalyst powder (0.10 g) was dispersed on the stainless steel omentum, which was fixed in the center of the reactor.The bottom of the

stirring for 120 min, the mixture was transferred to a clean flat Petri dish (diameter: 10 cm) and then left at room temperature for a day to allow the solvent to evaporate leaving a rigid gel.This gel was calcined at 900 C under Ar flow for 4 hours with a heating ramp of 1 C min -1 to decompose and carbonize the precursors.Finally, the silica matrix was removed using a 2 M NaOH aqueous solution and this etching process was repeated three times.The resulting composite photocatalyst is denoted as TiO 2
